New York{{cite web|url=http://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/NJD/head2head.html|title=New Jersey Devils Head-to-Head Results|work=hockey-reference.com|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC}} |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Largest Margin of Victory''' || 9–1 New Jersey
(March 19, 2000) |- ! style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | Post Season History |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Post Season Meetings''' || 4-1 (Rangers) |- |[[1992 Stanley Cup playoffs|1992 PDSF]] || Rangers won, 4-3 |- |[[1994 Stanley Cup playoffs|1994 ECF]] || Rangers won, 4-3 |- |[[1997 Stanley Cup playoffs|1997 ECSF]] || Rangers won, 4-1 |- |[[2006 Stanley Cup playoffs|2006 ECQF]] || Devils won, 4-0 |- |[[2008 Stanley Cup playoffs|2008 ECQF]] || Rangers won, 4-1 |} The '''[[New Jersey Devils]] - [[New York Rangers]] Rivalry''' (also known as the '''''Hudson River rivalry'''''), exist between two [[National Hockey League]] teams in the New York metropolitan area. The two teams are called "cross-river rivals."{{cite news|title=Rangers Dig Themselves a Hole, and Devils Push Them In|first=Lynn|last=Zinser|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 13, 2008|page=D5}} This is because [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[Midtown Manhattan]], where the Rangers play, is less than ten miles and across the Hudson River from the [[Prudential Center]] in downtown [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] (and previously, the [[Izod Center|Meadowlands Arena]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey|East Rutherford]]), the home ice of the Devils. Travel between both arenas is easily accomplished by both road (usually through the [[Lincoln Tunnel]]) and rail (along the [[Northeast Corridor]] and [[Port Authority Trans Hudson|PATH]]). ==Early history== The rivalry began when the Devils moved from [[Colorado]] to the [[New York metropolitan area]], in spite of the territorial fees paid to the Rangers, [[New York Islanders]], and [[Philadelphia Flyers]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/sports/owner-devils-are-not-moving.html?pagewanted=print|title=Owner: Devils are not Moving|last=Yannis|first=Alex|date=February 18, 1987|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=21 December 2009}} For over 25 years, fans of both the Rangers and Devils have seen the best out of both their clubs whenever they meet. Despite the Devils' overall playoff superiority since the 1990s, the first three playoff series between these teams were all Rangers victories. Their first meeting occurred in the spring of [[1992 Stanley Cup playoffs|1992]], when the [[Presidents' Trophy]]-winning Rangers survived a seven-game Patrick Division Semifinal series with the Devils.{{cite news|title=Rangers' Net Result: Let Devils Count Ways|first=Robert|last=Fachet|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 2, 1992|page=g06}}{{cite news|title=Rangers Vanquish the Devils and the Demons|last=Bondy|first=Filip|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 2, 1992|page=29}} ==1994 Eastern Conference Finals== The rivalry's most famous moments, however, are centered around the teams' second encounter: the Rangers' championship season of {{scfy|1994}} during the [[1994 Stanley Cup playoffs|Eastern Conference Finals]]. Although both teams were the top point-getters in the NHL in 1994 (the Presidents' Trophy-winning Rangers netting 112 and the Devils notching 106),{{cite book|last=Morrison|first=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Canada: My Greatest Day|year=2008|publisher=Key Porter Books|location=Toronto|isbn=978-1-55470-086-8|authorlink=Scott Morrison (journalist)|pages=106–109, 137}} the story entering the series was the Rangers' 6-0 record against New Jersey that regular season. In the final weeks of the regular season, the Devils were chasing the Rangers for the best record in the NHL. In response, the New York news media pushed Rangers Coach [[Mike Keenan]] to get the Rangers to win the Presidents' Trophy. He replied: "I want to play Game 7 of the Stanley Cup in [[Madison Square Garden]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/newsprint.htm?id=425396|title=Keenan knows Game 7 pressure|date=June 11, 2009|first=John|last=McGourty|work=NHL.com|accessdate=October 22, 2010}} However, all ideas of a quick New York series were soon ended after Game 1, a 4-3 double [[overtime (hockey)|overtime]] victory that was sealed by the Devils' [[Stephane Richer]].{{cite news|title=Double Overtime Winds Up Devils' Time|last=LaPointe|first=Joe|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 16, 1994|page=C1}} The Rangers routed the Devils 4-0 in Game 2, and used a double overtime goal by [[StÃ©phane Matteau|Stephane Matteau]] to take a 2-1 lead after Game 3.{{cite news|title=As Shots Ring Out in Overtime, Rangers Triumph|last=LaPointe|first=Joe|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 20, 1994|page=B11}} After dropping Games 4 and 5, the Rangers faced elimination going to New Jersey for Game 6. Prior to the game, Rangers captain [[Mark Messier]] guaranteed a victory in Game 6 at the Meadowlands; with the Rangers down 2-0 to the Devils, Messier scored a hat trick to tie the series at 3-3 and send it back to New York for Game 7. In Game 7, the Devils' [[Valeri Zelepukin]] tied the game with 7.7 seconds left in regulation,{{cite news|title=2 Overtimes Later, It's a Final and It's the Rangers|last=LaPointe|first=Joe|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 28, 1994|page=27|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/28/sports/hockey-2-overtimes-later-it-s-a-final-and-it-s-the-rangers.html?pagewanted=print&src=pm|accessdate=June 5, 2011}} but thanks to another [[Stephane Matteau|Matteau]] goal in double overtime the Rangers won the series and went on to win the [[1994 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] over the [[Vancouver Canucks]], also in seven games. Interestingly, the first six games were won by the team that lost that respective game in 1992. That trend was reversed when the Rangers won Game 7 in '94. The Devils recovered from that crushing defeat in 1994 and won the Stanley Cup [[1995 Stanley Cup Finals|the following year]],{{cite news|title=New Jersey and the Cup—Perfect Together; Sweep Makes New Jersey and the Cup Perfect Together|first=Alex|last=Yannis|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 25, 1995|page=S1}} though they had to go through another of their own [[DevilsâFlyers rivalry|rival]]s (also a great [[FlyersâRangers rivalry|rival]] of the Rangers) in [[1995 Stanley Cup playoffs|that year's Eastern Conference Finals]], the [[Philadelphia Flyers]],{{cite news|title=Banishing Game 6 Ghosts, Devils Set Sights on Cup|first=Alex|last=Yannis|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 14, 1995|page=B11}} making showdowns between the two teams during the {{nhly|1995}} season showdowns between the Stanley Cup champions of the previous two seasons. ==1997 Playoffs== The third Devils-Rangers playoff series happened only three years later. The Rangers, led by Messier, eliminated the Devils in the [[1997 Stanley Cup playoffs|1997 Eastern Conference Semifinals]]. New Jersey was limited to five goals in the five-game series, including two [[shutout]] losses. ==1998 to 2006== From the start of 1998, however, the [[pendulum]] began to swing the other way. New Jersey dominated New York during the regular season in the late 1990s and early 2000s. At one point, the Devils had an unbeaten streak against the Rangers throughout 23 regular season games going 15-0-8; starting on February 17, 1997, and ending March 31, 2001 â an undefeated streak spanning four years. At the end of the {{nhly|2005}}, the Devils had won 11 games straight â the second such streak of the season â and capped off the run by winning the [[Atlantic Division (NHL)|Atlantic Division]] in comeback fashion against the [[Montreal Canadiens]], a division win made all the more exciting by the fact that the Devils had been 22 points out of the lead just 3 months prior, with many thinking the team wouldn't make the playoffs. Meanwhile, the Rangers had the division lead for most of the latter part of the season, but fell victim to a losing skid as the season came to a close. The Devils took the Division title away from the Rangers by ending the season with 1 more point than New York. As fate would have it, the white-hot Devils met the Rangers in their 4th playoff meeting in the 2006 Eastern Conference Quarterfinals. The result was a four-game sweep by New Jersey over their cross-river rivals for the first time ever in franchise history. ==Since 2006== [[Image:Averyrule.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Sean Avery]] distracts [[Martin Brodeur]] during Game 3 of the 2008 Eastern Conference Quarterfinals.]] Two years later, the teams would meet yet again in the playoffs for the 5th time, in the 2008 Eastern Conference Quarterfinals. After long time Devil [[Scott Gomez]] signed with the Rangers before the 2007â08 season, he has been severely booed by Devils fans at the Prudential Center every time he touched the puck.{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/f/print/sports/rangers/item_SgR3yp3TnNZEecjDOhodwN|title=Hurtin' Gomez Enjoys Some Rib-Tickling Fun|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|first=Jay|last=Greenberg|date=April 10, 2008|accessdate=2009-01-22}} Gomez scored 3 assists in Game 1 and 2 goals in Game 4 against his former team en route to a Rangers series win. In Game 3, Ranger [[Sean Avery]] used a tactic to screen opposing goaltender [[Martin Brodeur]]. While essentially ignoring the play on the ice when his team had a two-man advantage, Avery faced Brodeur and waved his hands and stick in front of him in an attempt to distract him and block his view. Although not illegal, many NHL commentators and players described Avery's actions as inappropriate.{{cite news| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=3346729&type=story| title=NHL amends unsportsmanlike conduct rule in response to Avery's antics |work=[[ESPN.com]]|date=April 14, 2008| accessdate=2008-04-14|author=Associated Press}} The following day, the NHL issued an [[Sean Avery|interpretation of the league's unsportsmanlike conduct rule]] to cover actions such as the one employed by Avery. Following the Rangers victory in Game 5 of the series during the hand-shake line, Brodeur shook the hand of every Ranger except Avery. When asked what happened after the game, Avery said "I guess I like men."{{cite web|url=http://faceoffcircle.net/2008/04/18/quote-of-the-year-from-sean-avery/|title=Quote of the Year from Sean Avery|publisher=Faceoff Circle|date=2008-04-18|accessdate=2009-01-22}} During the {{nhly|2009}} season, there was a moment of peace in the rivalry with both captains, Rangers' [[Chris Drury]] and Devils' [[Jamie Langenbrunner]] winning silver medals as members the [[Ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics|U.S. men's ice hockey team]] during the [[2010 Winter Olympics|Vancouver Olympics]]. However, the rivalry was revived because both coaches, Rangers [[John Tortorella]] and Devils [[Jacques Lemaire]] were on different team's benches. Tortorella was an assistant coach for the U.S. team, Lemaire with the Canadian team, which won the gold medal. The Rangers won 4 of 6 meetings between the two teams in the {{nhly|2010}} season, and won the last meeting of the season to make the playoffs.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2011/04/09/sp-rangerswin.html|title=Rangers clinch playoff spot with Canes loss|date=April 9, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2011|author=Associated Press|work=CBC Sports}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/recap.htm?id=2010021215|title=Rangers beat Devils, then make playoffs|date=April 9, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2011|work=NHL|publisher=National Hockey League|first=Dave|last=Lozo}} Hours after the Rangers beat the Devils 5–2 in their last game of the season on April 9,{{cite web|title=Rangers crush Devils to hold serve|url=http://rangers.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=558905&navid=DL|NYR|home|date=April 9, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2011|first=Jim|last=Cerny|work=Rangers.NHL.com|publisher=National Hockey League}} the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] beat the [[Carolina Hurricanes]] 6–2 to help the Rangers reach the [[2011 Stanley Cup playoffs]].{{cite web|title=Lightning knock 'Canes out of playoffs with 6-2 win|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/recap.htm?id=2010021219|date=April 9, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2011|work=NHL.com|publisher=National Hockey League}} Both teams were in opposite directions during the season. The Rangers finished 44–33–5, while the Devils finished the season under .500 for the first time since the {{nhly|1990}} season, with a record of 38–39–5.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/recap.htm?id=2010021226|title=Lemaire steps down after Devils' win over Bruins|date=April 10, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2011|first=Mike G.|last=Morreale|work=NHL.com}} The DevilsâRangers series will debut at it's latest date since the Devils moved to New Jersey in 1986 during the 2011-12 season. For the previous six seasons the teams had meet at least once in October.{{Cite news|first=Andrew|last=Gross|title=DevilsâRangers' series starts later that usual.|url=http://www.northjersey.com/sports/pro_sports/hockey/devils/124475409_Devils-Rangers__series_starts_later_than_usual.html|newspaper=[[The Bergen Record]]|date=June 24, 2011|accessdate=July 15, 2011}} ==Reaction== Fans on both sides have agreed the rivalry has become even stronger as of late, due in large part to the fact that both teams have shown much more parity towards each other. Many hockey analysts within the media have referred to them as "''mirror teams''" given their many similarities. Since the [[2004â05 NHL lockout|NHL Lockout]], the two teams have met a total of 43 times (as of March 25, 2010) including [[postseason]] games. The Devils have won 21 of these contests, the Rangers have won 24. Many Rangers fans have been seen burning Devils memorabilia after Ranger victories over the Devils, and lighting their [[cigarette]]s with it, while exiting [[Madison Square Garden]]. Devils fans, meanwhile, enjoy making [[confetti]] which reads "Rangers Suck" and handing them out during games at the Continental Airlines Arena and currently at the [[Prudential Center]]. The Jersey fans also have a cheer that is yelled and whistled at every game. In response to the "Let's Go Band"/"[[Denis Potvin|Potvin Sucks]]" chant of Rangers fans against the Islanders, the Devils fans at the [[Prudential Center]] cheer "Rangers Suck." This chant, just like the Potvin chant being heard whether the Rangers are playing the Islanders or not, is heard at every Devils home game.{{YouTube|id=Z19cGrS2ISc|title=Rangers Suck!}} The Rangers and Devils rivalry is popular among fans, due to the geographic proximity, which is seen as a battle between the neighboring states of New York and New Jersey. While Devils fans will occasionally attend games at Madison Square Garden in large numbers (especially during the final two games of the 2006 series sweep), Rangers fans have historically showed up at both the Meadowlands and now the Prudential Center in extremely large numbers. Fans of both teams have also shown considerable hostility towards each other's goalies. Rangers fans have often battered Devils goalie Martin Brodeur with chants of "Marty! Marty! Marty!" after goals scored on him during games between the two teams. Conversely, Devils fans will chant "Henrik! Henrik! Henrik!" at Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist after the Devils score on him. Recently, there have been parting shots taken by players and media at each organization through written words. In ''Beyond the Crease'', an autobiography written by Martin Brodeur, he writes; "I hate the Rangers, and [[Lou Lamoriello|Lou]] hates them to death."{{cite book|last=Brodeur|first=Martin|authorlink=Martin Brodeur|first2=Damien|last2=Cox|title=Beyond the Crease|publisher=Wiley Press|year=2006|pages=261|isbn=978-0470838518|authorlink2=Damien Cox}} During their last playoff meet, actor/director [[Kevin Smith]] was asked to have a blog commenting on the series, which could be read on the NHL's official website. After Game 3 he wrote; "''No Devils fan can truly pinpoint why we hate our cross-river rivals as much as we do. Even so, Devils fans live to hate the Rangers. Sometimes, it feels like a large cross-section of those folks in the stands at the Rock (and formerly at the Meadowlands) aren't there so much to love on the Devils as they are to hate on New York. Even when the boys in blue aren't anywhere near the building, we're still seething about their very existence. You'd think we'd hold a special place in our hearts for the Rangers, as they gave us our first ever win back in 1982. Granted, they don't roll over for us as much as Philly does (except, y'know - in that last game this season), but the Rangers've been hoisted up high on the Devils' pitchfork enough times (the '06 four-zip playoffs come to mind) to warrant at least a degree of affection right?''"{{cite web|url=http://fans.nhl.com/members/Kevin_Smith11/blogs/10855|title=Live to Hate the Rangers|authorlink=Kevin Smith|publisher=NHL.com|date=2008-04-10|accessdate=2009-01-22|first=Kevin|last=Smith}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==In popular culture== This rivalry was satirized in [[pop-culture]] with the [[Seinfeld]] episode "[[The Face Painter]]" in which [[David Puddy]], a hard-core Devils fan, paints his face red at a playoff game against the Rangers in the Garden, to the embarrassment of [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry]], [[Cosmo Kramer|Kramer]], and [[Elaine Benes|Elaine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/seinfeld/the-face-painter/episode/2349/summary.html?tag=episode_tabs;overview|title=Seinfeld: The Face Painter|publisher=TV.com|accessdate=2009-01-22}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{New Jersey Devils}} {{New York Rangers}} {{NHL rivalries}} {{DEFAULTSORT:DevilsâRangers Rivalry}} [[Category:National Hockey League rivalries]] [[Category:New Jersey Devils]] [[Category:New York Rangers]]
